holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [The Royal Tour of Australia]
results.brief_description:
This film is a documentary of the visit of Queen Elizabeth II to Australia in 1954. A highlight is an event at the MCG in Melbourne in which 17,000 children participated. At one point, the excited children break rank and surround the royals jeep to get a closer view so that Prince Philip starts to shoo them out of the way of the vehicle.

Another Prince Philip moment is at the Davis Cup tennis tournament in Melbourne where he is seen speaking at length to the coach and the players who assume they should pass by quickly.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘The Royal Tour of Australia’ and ‘The Queen visits Hobart’
00:00:14:00 view of a ship on the water followed by the Queen and Prince Phillip looking through binoculars from the ship’s deck
00:00:30:00 waving to the crowd, sailing into harbour and looking out over the waving crowds and military assembly
00:01:04:00 the Queen and Prince Philip stand in the back of a military jeep, waving to huge cheering crowd as they pass by
00:01:10:00 title ‘The Queen in Melbourne’
00:01:17:00 the Queen descending the steps at Parliament House, Melbourne accompanied by be-wigged members of the judiciary and other officials
00:01:40:00 greeting the crowds at the MCG (Melbourne Cricket Ground) including veterans in wheelchairs
00:02:11:00 an young girl and boy present flowers to the Queen and Prince Philip
00:02:18:00 the Queen and Prince Philip keenly watching horse racing at Flemington Racecourse in Melbourne
00:03:29:00 at the Davis Cup match in Melbourne, the Queen presents a trophy to coach Harry Hopman, and players Ken Rosewall and Lou Hoad
00:04:04:00 a visit to Melbourne war memorial, the Shrine of Remembrance where the Queen delivers a dedication speech, after which the Queen presses a button which lights the eternal flame in the forecourt
00:05:35:00 military aircraft fly overhead in the shape of a capital E as Prince Philip attends the Flinders Naval base in Victoria, and watches a parade of naval personnel, including women (an unusual element according to the narration)
00:06:19:00 the royals watch a parade at Point Cook airforce base
00:06:40:00 the Queen and Prince Philip are shown the operations of the open cut coal mine at Yallourn in Victoria by the Chairman of the State Board for Electricity, Mr Hunt
00:07:18:00 children participate in an exhibition of maypole dancing at the MCG for the Queen and Prince Philip
00:08:05:00 the Queen and Prince Philip in an open jeep, with Prince Philip ‘directing traffic’ as children surround the vehicle
00:08:14:00 title ‘The end’

Note - 08/09/2022 Ann Jones (née Vernon) wrote to ACMI to say she was 10 years old and was from West Coburg Primary School. When the word ‘Welcome’ was formed she was at the top corner of the ‘C’. I remember Her Majesty driving past us and waving.

group_siblings.title: [Donald Duck in Matching Tricks; The Charging Bull]

results.title: NBC
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: This film features flashing lights that may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy.

The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This short film features Frank Eidlitz’s early experiments with light, colour and motion. Commissioned by the television network National Broadcasting Company (NBC) to reinterpret the station’s classic peacock logo, Eidlitz produced a series of film experiments with kaleidoscopic spinning lights.

To create these visuals, Eidlitz covered a series of disks with pieces of reflective paper and fluorescent colours, which he then placed on an apparatus that spun the disks at a high speed. The motion could be varied and stopped at any time, allowing the artist to create varying designs and images.

Opening with a close-up of a woman’s face covered in reflected lights, the majority of the film is comprised of flashing lights and spinning colours. The NBC peacock symbol appears intermittently throughout the film, at the forefront of the image.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is a snapshot into suburban family life, showing a child’s birthday party.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 boy with a birthday cake
00:01:50:00 group of boys playing and wrestling

results.title: Peace in action
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Peace is everyone’s responsibility. The peace program views peace issues being developed and taught in schools. Examples from primary and postprimary schools include art, student initiatives, plays, student councils and community interest. Professor Charlesworth raises issues for further discussion in schools

results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris, Trevor Lunn and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: A series of programmes which aim to help adult migrants communicate in everyday situations. Tina swaps her sons jeans for another size. Home tutor program by the Adult Migrant Information Service.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is entitled ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ and is credited to Tibor and Merna Koller. It is staged as a narrative film, following a teenage girl, presumably the couple’s daughter, visiting a kennel to buy a puppy and bringing it home.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ followed by ‘Produced by Tibor & Merna Koller 1968’
00:00:29:00 calendar indicating the date 28 November 1968
00:00:36:00 footage of a teenage girl sleeping, interspersed with footage of puppies, indicating she is dreaming
00:01:37:00 the newspaper boy arrives on a bicycle
00:02:15:00 sign ‘Victorian Animal Aid Trust’
00:02:31:00 girl patting puppies through a diamond wire fence
00:04:39:00 girl and puppy playing in the front yard of their house
00:04:51:00 giving the dog a bath in the laundry sink
00:06:00:00 having a nap in the sun together
00:06:11:00 title card ‘The End, Daddy DID buy me a Bow-Bow’

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Macao, China and Hong Kong in the 1960s. The quality of the film can be challenging at times (shaky, sometimes dark and damaged) but it is well worth it for scenes of the busy waterways and street life around Hong Kong Island, Kowloon and Macau. Billy particularly focuses on the many different watercraft such as passenger and cargo ships, ferries, row boats, houseboats and plenty of wonderful traditional junks.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:46:00 scenes filmed from a train as it travels past cultivated fields, farmers, bullock teams, field hands
00:01:25:00 traditional house by as river
00:01:19:00 young children working on logs at a timber mill
00:02:12:00 field workers closer to the camera
00:02:30:00 small, covered junks on the water in a harbour
00:02:45:00 busy port
00:03:05:00 large group of moored, small house boats with mountains in the background
00:03:22:00 children playing on a beach
00:03:50:00 ferries and traditional sailing boats as well as large ships
00:04:29:00 large ferry
00:04:55:00 traditional junk sailing by a large modern ship
00:05:45:00 city residential apartment buildings with mountains in background.
00:06:18:00 city streets, shops and signs, including one for ‘Coca Cola’
00:08:07:00 new and old watercraft
00:08:75:00 colourful passenger ferry
00:08:35:00 lovely traditional junk in full sail
00:09:30:00 a child points at the camera while playing with friends
00:10:00:00 international shipping
00:10:30:00 wonderful striped canvas tent bathing boxes followed by scenes of locals relaxing at the beach.
00:12:52:00 another notable traditional junk sailing by the camera
00:14:11:00 vegetable sellers in low lying boats
results.description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Macao, China and Hong Kong in the 1960s. The quality of the film can be challenging at times (shaky, sometimes dark and damaged) but it is well worth it for scenes of the busy waterways and street life around Hong Kong Island, Kowloon and Macau. Billy particularly focuses on the many different watercraft such as passenger and cargo ships, ferries, row boats, houseboats and plenty of wonderful traditional junks.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:46:00 scenes filmed from a train as it travels past cultivated fields, farmers, bullock teams, field hands
00:01:25:00 traditional house by as river
00:01:19:00 young children working on logs at a timber mill
00:02:12:00 field workers closer to the camera
00:02:30:00 small, covered junks on the water in a harbour
00:02:45:00 busy port
00:03:05:00 large group of moored, small house boats with mountains in the background
00:03:22:00 children playing on a beach
00:03:50:00 ferries and traditional sailing boats as well as large ships
00:04:29:00 large ferry
00:04:55:00 traditional junk sailing by a large modern ship
00:05:45:00 city residential apartment buildings with mountains in background.
00:06:18:00 city streets, shops and signs, including one for ‘Coca Cola’
00:08:07:00 new and old watercraft
00:08:75:00 colourful passenger ferry
00:08:35:00 lovely traditional junk in full sail
00:09:30:00 a child points at the camera while playing with friends
00:10:00:00 international shipping
00:10:30:00 wonderful striped canvas tent bathing boxes followed by scenes of locals relaxing at the beach.
00:12:52:00 another notable traditional junk sailing by the camera
00:14:11:00 vegetable sellers in low lying boats

group.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

In this film, Billy travels to Taiping, Malaysia and Tarakan, Borneo and then journeys throughout Australia during 1961.

This film was originally made using standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film has a few scenes from Billy’s travels to Taiping in Malaysia before moving on to Sydney and Melbourne. Billy includes some lovely scenes of being at sea, ships and shipping. The scenes in Sydney include the Harbour, the Bridge and some busy streets. In Melbourne we see the Moomba Parade, trams and vintage cars along St Kilda Road, the Yarra River and the Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southbank.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 on board ship
00:00:33:00 two passengers disembarking in Malaysia
00:00:43:00 views of traditional Malaysian housing
00:00:55:00 people cycling along roads in Taiping, Malaysia
00:01:09:00 women standing with local children in Taiping, all smiling at the camera
00:01:20:00 a woman walking toward embarkation area for a ship
00:02:12:00 great shot of a passenger ship speeding along through the water
00:03:45:00 (possibly) Pulau Pising Lighthouse on Banana Island in the Malacca Straits.
00:04:58:00 a glimpse of some passengers on board ship as they lean over the rail coming into Sydney Harbour.
00:05:43:00 a large liner at berth
00:06:10:00 military ship in Sydney Harbour
00:06:40:00 travelling over the Harbour Bridge by car
00:07:23:00 yachts on the Harbour
00:08:43:00 sign for ‘Wollongong’ followed by an early model Holden (EK)
00:12:13:00 Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southgate, Melbourne, followed by the Yarra River, river boats and Princes Bridge.
00:12:54:00 Circa 1960s (and earlier) cars and trams on St Kilda Road in Melbourne
00:13:13:00 Moomba Parade in Melbourne
00:13:39:00 a decorated ‘A.L.P’ (Australian Labor Party) parade float
00:13:43:00 the ‘Magga Dan Esberg’ ship at a berth.
00:16:50:00 Anzac Day Parade.

results.title: What kids and adults think of maths
results.brief_description: Bill Newton interviews people in the City Square to obtain their views on mathematics, particularly the relevance of school mathematics.
